clinical_study.brief_title: Influence of Cognition and Gait on Falls
clinical_study.official_title: Predicting Falls Among Institutionalized and Non-institutionalized Older Adults: The Role of Cognition and Gait Speed

brief_summary.textblock: The study analyses if cognition and gait speed can predict falls in a community-dwelling people and ambulant long term care residents

detailed_description.textblock:
Falls are some of the most common events among elderly people. The odds of recurrent falls increase every year, which can cause impairment in basic activities of daily living, social isolation, fear of falling again and death. The aim of the present study is to analyze the role of cognition and gait speed as predictors to falls in institutionalized and non-institutionalized elderly people.
Methods:Twenty-five individuals living in a long-term care facility and 25 non-institutionalized individuals participated in the study. A questionnaire about their history of falls, tests to evaluate cognition (global and executive function) and a pedometer with an accelerometer to measure kinematic variables were applied.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognitive predictor of falls assessed with the Mini-Mental State Examination
primary_outcome.description: To measure cognitive predictor will be used Mini-Mental State Examination

secondary_outcome.measure: Executive function predictor of falls assessed with the Wisconsin Card Sort Test
secondary_outcome.description: To measure executive function will be used Wisconsin Card Sort Test

secondary_outcome.measure: Gait speed predictor of falls assessed with an accelerometer
secondary_outcome.description: To measure gait speed will be used an accelerometer

intervention.description: Observational study: kinematic variables, falls and executive function were analyzed

study_pop.textblock: Twenty-five individuals living in a long term care facility and twenty-five older adults from community

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- People who could walk with or without ambulation devices
- Mini-Mental State Examination score according to schooling
Exclusion Criteria:
- Terminal illnesses
- Bedridden
- Unable to see or hear
- Use of benzodiazepines
